ASRC RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

At American Synthetic Rubber Company, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner. We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment. This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:

* A description of our facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's Risk Management Plan (RMP) regulation
* An overview of our accidental release prevention programs
* A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by EPA's RMP rule
* An overview of our emergency response program
* An overview of planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely
  affecting our employees, the public, and the environment
* The certifications that EPA's RMP rule requires us to provide
* The detailed information (called data elements) about our risk management program

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

American Synthetic Rubber Company is located on a 60.5 acre site in the Southwest section of Jefferson County, Kentucky within the industrial area known as Rubbertown. Manufacturing operations are conducted on a seven day continuous basis. We employ approximately 345 individuals who work nominal shift hours of 7:00 a.m. - 7:00 p.m., or 7:00 p.m. - 7:00 a.m. Approximately 260 employees are on site weekdays between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. Approximately 50 employees operate the plant at all other times.

Product lines include solution polybutadiene (BR) and solution styrene butadiene (SSBR) rubbers, which are utilized primarily in the manufacturing of automobile tires,

and a polybutadiene - acrylonitrile - acrylic acid (PBAN) terpolymer which is utilized as a component in the manufacturing of some solid rocket propellants.

Bulk raw materials are received via tank car and tank truck. Non - bulk raw material receipts (drum /carton commodities) are generally received via common carrier. Facilities for receiving and storage of the more volatile process materials are located outdoors in areas as remote as practical from the main plant processes. These installations are typically protected and provided with a means of secondary containment (e.g. dikes) in order to minimize hazards resulting from spillage. The physical transfer of raw materials from transport container to storage and on to the various processing units is accomplished by means of pumps and/or inert gas pressure.

BR and SSBR, reaction products of butadiene and butadiene / styrene respectively, are manufactured in a continuous polymerization process utilizing toluene as a diluent. Organometallic catalysts are added to initiate the reaction and carry it to the desired level of conversion. The resulting polymer solution is then pumped through a series of flash distillation units to recover the unreacted butadiene and a significant portion of the solvent, leaving a more viscous solution.

The majority of the remaining solvent is then separated (stripped) from the polymer using a steam distillation process. This occurs by bringing the polymerized rubber into contact with hot water and steam. Stripped vapors arising from this operation are condensed and recovered for reuse. The remaining crumb water slurry is then dewatered, dried, baled, packaged and warehoused.

PBAN, a reaction product of butadiene/acrylonitrile/acrylic acid, is a batch process. An emulsifying agent or soap is utilized to facilitate the dispersion of the ingredients in a water medium and a catalyst is added to initiate the reaction and accelerate it to completion. The polymerized emulsion is commonly refer

red to as latex. Unreacted compounds are either recovered or discharged to the wastewater treatment plant. The latex is coagulated by the addition of brine and subsequently dried. Finished product is then transferred to hold tanks pending laboratory analysis and on to storage.

In our processes, we use the following chemicals that EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant off site consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release:

Toxics

Acrylonitrile. We maintain an on site inventory that is greater than the RMP threshold quantity of 20,000 pounds. This chemical is one of the reactants used in the manufacturing of PBAN polymer.

Ammonia. We maintain an on site inventory that is greater than the RMP threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds. Ammonia is used solely as a refrigerant in various parts of our manufacturing process.

Titanium Tetrachloride. We maintain an on site inventory that is greater than the RMP threshold quantity of 2,500 pounds. This material is used as a catalyst in the manufacture of BR and SSBR rubber. It is delivered and stored in 1,150 Ib DOT shipping containers until it is introduced into our processes.

Flammables:

 1,3-Butadiene. We maintain an on site inventory that is greater than the RMP threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds. This chemical is the primary raw material used in the manufacturing of our products.

 Hydrogen. We maintain an on site inventory that is less than the RMP threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds.

Our accidental release prevention programs and our contingency planning efforts allow us to effectively manage the hazards that are posed to our employees, the public, and the environment by our use of these chemicals.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals. Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs includ

ing:

*  Process safety information
*  Process hazard analysis
*  Operating procedures
*  Training
*  Mechanical integrity
*  Management of change 
*  Pre-startup review
*  Compliance audits
*  Incident investigation
*  Employee participation
*  Hot work permit
*  Contractor evaluation and screening

As part of our prevention efforts, we have implemented the following chemical-specific prevention steps:

*  Installed sealless 1,3-butadiene pumps
*  Installed sealless acrylonitrile pumps
*  Maintained a 1,3-Butadiene decontamination system
*  Removed unused ammonia equipment and piping from service
*  Removed unused 1,3 - butadiene equipment and piping from service
*  Maintained acrylonitrile area detection system (Baseline gas chromatograph)
*  Installed a thermal oxidizer to more efficiently destroy 1,3 - butadiene, titanium tetrachloride and acrylonitrile vapors
*  Maintained activated carbon canisters to collect vented acrylonitrile vapors 
*  Mainatined secondary containment for all vessels storing covered chemicals
*  Upgraded combustible gas detection instrumentation for 1,3-butadiene
*  Maintained foam deluge system to protect acrylonitrile unloading station
*  Installed fire-safe valves beneath 1,3-butadiene storage tanks
*  Maintained certification program for training employees
*  Expanded the leak detection and repair program (LDAR) to not only include 1,3-butadiene but added acrylonitrile components also
*  Provided schools within our scenario circles with communications equipment to monitor
    the local fire department and emergency responders

These individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases. Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management systems set for the way we do business, and we have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 

We maintain an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning. Our program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations. Furthermore, we coordinate our plan with the community emergency response plan.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The following is a list of improvements that we are planning to implement at the facility to help prevent and/or better respond to acidental chemical releases:

* Maintain chemical response training for emergency response personnel
* Maintain ISO 14000 program certification
* Implement process hazard analysis recommendations
* Implement mechanical integrity recommendations
* Maintain communication efforts in the event of accidental releases through the use of the RCALL system.
